trans-unit.source: You can create Azure storage queues by using Visual Studio **Server Explorer**.
trans-unit.target: You can create Azure storage queues by using Visual Studio **Server Explorer**.

trans-unit.source: In Server Explorer, expand the **Azure** node for your subscription, expand the **Storage** node and the node for the storage account you specified in the Azure Storage connected service.
trans-unit.target: In Server Explorer, expand the **Azure** node for your subscription, expand the **Storage** node and the node for the storage account you specified in the Azure Storage connected service.

trans-unit.source: Select the **Queues** node and choose **Create Queue** from the context menu.
trans-unit.target: Select the **Queues** node and choose **Create Queue** from the context menu.

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the container and choose **OK**.
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the container and choose **OK**.

trans-unit.source: By default, the new container is private and you must specify your storage access key to download blobs from this container.
trans-unit.target: By default, the new container is private and you must specify your storage access key to download blobs from this container.

trans-unit.source: If you want to make the files in the container public, select the container in **Server Explorer** and press `F4` to display the **Properties** window.
trans-unit.target: If you want to make the files in the container public, select the container in **Server Explorer** and press `F4` to display the **Properties** window.

trans-unit.source: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.
trans-unit.target: Anyone on the Internet can see blobs in a public container, but you can modify or delete them only if you have the appropriate access key.
